description.narrative: Strengthening Local Capacities for Resilience and Recovery (SLCRR Top-up) T05-EUTF-NOA-LY-09 T05.1253 Implementation period: 1 May 2020 – 30 April 2023 In more than 29 municipalities

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative: 1.1 Number of needs assessments based on a participatory approach conducted to identify priorities for enhancing basic services. 1.2 Number of municipal staff with enhanced skills for improved service delivery. 1.3. Number of municipalities supported to improve their basic services [disaggregated by type (civil works/equipment) and sector (health, education, water, sanitation, electricity, etc.]. 1.4. Number of people in targeted municipalities with access to basic services [disaggregated by sector and beneficiary group (IDPs, migrants, refugees, and where feasible by gender and age)]. 2.1 Number of community members trained on social cohesion, community security and conflict mediation disaggregated by beneficiary group (IDPs, migrants and refugees, and where feasible by gender and age). 2.2 Number of municipal staff trained on social cohesion, community security and conflict mediation, where feasible disaggregated by job position, gender and age. 2.3 Number of local activities/ initiatives supported by UNDP towards peaceful coexistence, community security and social cohesion. 2.4 Number of personnel from local rule of law institutions trained to acquire technical skills on social cohesion and community security. 2.5 Number of Rule of Law facilities refurbished and/or provided with essential non-lethal equipment. 3.1 Number of local economic assessments conducted to identify relevant economic interventions in targeted municipalities 3.2 Number of new jobs created with UNDP support (disaggregated by beneficiary group (IDPs, migrants and refugees, and where feasible by gender and age) 3.3 Number of start-ups and small businesses supported/created in Libya (disaggregated by gender) 3.4 Number of demand-driven apprenticeship programmes organized in partnership with private sector companies. 3.5. Number of people benefiting from apprenticeship programmes disaggregated by gender, age and type of training (e.g. TVET, IT and skills training etc.)

comment.narrative:
Output 1 - Enhanced provision of basic services at local level targeting the most vulnerable groups - including Internally Displaced Populations (IDPs) and returnees - as well as migrants and refugees
Out of 22 targeted municipalities, 19 local platforms were engaged to facilitate needs analysis, namely Al Brega, Jalu, Jaghra, Ojla, Mrada, Robyana, Tazerbo, Tobruk, Al Qala, Nalut, Achargya, Al Grefa, Bint Baya, Idri Achati, Ghadames, Azahra, Baten El Jabal, Qasr Alkhyar, Derj. The engagement of the platforms in the remaining three municipalities, namely Mslat, Al Riyayna, and Jufra (including Fugha, Sukana, Waddan, Hun and Zallah) is expected in Q4 2021.
Consultative meetings were held engaging local platforms including Mayors, representatives of the Municipal Councils as well as community leaders, Muktar Mhalla (District Chief), women, youth and CSOs networks. This mechanism allowed for a participatory and inclusive consultative process for the identification and prioritization of needs to enhance provision of basic services at local level with a focus on the most critical sectors, such as water and sanitation, waste management, energy, education and healthcare services, including response to COVID-19.
19 participatory assessments have been completed and key priorities identified in the following municipalities while ensuring do-no harm approach: Al Brega, Jaghra, Jalu, Mrada, Ojla, Robyana, Tazerbo, Tobruk, Al Qala, Azahra, Baten El Jabal, Derj, Ghadames, Nalut, Qasr Alkhyar, Achargya, Al Grefa, Bint Baya, Idri Achati. This activity entailed fast track diagnostics, feasibility studies for infrastructure works and/or equipment delivery and preparation of procurement related documents (BoQs and technical specifications).
Extensive consultations have taken place with MoLG/General Secretary of Local Government, relevant municipalities as well as other international partners (including GIZ), regarding the strategy and methodology for the capacity building activity and how UNDP’s contribution would contribute to national Local Governance Training Institute being supported by other international partners, including the EU and GIZ.
Conflict-sensitive workshops have taken place in four (4) municipalities, namely, Achargia, Al Grefa, Idri Achati and Tobruk, while additional four (4) are expected be finalized by the end of this year for the municipalities of Alryaynah, Jufra, Mslata and Qasr Alkhyar.
To respond to the most urgent needs identified in WASH and health sectors, including response to COVID-19, the project has started the procurement process for over 40 sets of equipment, including sewage trucks, garbage trucks, water tankers and ambulances among other to be delivered to 16 municipalities, in addition to 6 critical civil works identified in 3 municipalities. By the end of its implementation period, this project component aims to reach 0.7 million beneficiaries in 22 municipalities.
1.1 Number of needs assessments based on a participatory approach conducted to identify priorities for enhancing basic services. - 19 completed. 3 ongoing. 1.2 Number of municipal staff with enhanced skills for improved service delivery. - 0 Strategy being finalised with MoLG. 1.3. Number of municipalities supported to improve their basic services [disaggregated by type (civil works/equipment) and sector (health, education, water, sanitation, electricity, etc.]. - 25 (Baseline 24 + New 1). 1 new municipality of Derj (2 equipment in health sector). Other ongoing activities are in 3 municip. for civil works, 16 municip. for equipment, 16 municip. for WASH, and 6 municip. for Health. 1.4. Number of people in targeted municipalities with access to basic services [disaggregated by sector and beneficiary group (IDPs, migrants, refugees, and where feasible by gender and age)]. - 1,890 direct beneficiaries (of which approx. 40% women) with better access to Health (Derj)
Output 2 - Capacities of target communities and local stakeholders enhanced towards social cohesion, community security and rule of law.
A call for proposal was launched in September 2021 targeting NGOs/CSOs in 7 municipalities. Selected local NGOs/CSOs will implement local initiatives that propose concrete solutions to building peace, harmonization of societies through inclusion and empowerment of women, youth, persons with disabilities, IDPs, returnees, refugees and migrants via an inclusive social cohesion approach. A total of 19 project proposals were received, and the selection is under the process.
2.1 Number of community members trained on social cohesion, community security and conflict mediation disaggregated by beneficiary group (IDPs, migrants and refugees, and where feasible by gender and age). - 0 2.2 Number of municipal staff trained on social cohesion, community security and conflict mediation, where feasible disaggregated by job position, gender and age. - 0 Strategy being finalized with MoLG 2.3 Number of local activities/ initiatives supported by UNDP towards peaceful coexistence, community security and social cohesion. - 5 (baseline). Call for proposal was launched and 19 initiative proposals were received from NGOs/CSOs in 7 municipalities. 2.4 Number of personnel from local rule of law institutions trained to acquire technical skills on social cohesion and community security. - 0 pending finalization of the capacity buildling strategy by MoI and MoJ 2.5 Number of Rule of Law facilities refurbished and/or provided with essential non-lethal equipment. - 0 Selected 2 facilities: The Primary Court and Prosecution Office of North Tripoli.
Output 3 - Employment opportunities created and individuals supported to develop economic income generating activities.
Under the Re-Start-Up Marathon, 10 selected entrepreneurs from Sebha and Benghazi received grants of up to US$40,000 along with business training and mentoring to further develop and implement their businesses. These entrepreneurs are expected to create over 60 new jobs, including the 11 jobs created so far. The start-ups incubated and supported through this activity developed solutions to market gaps in food processing, agriculture, delivery, e-commerce, digitalization and other services.
3.1 Number of local economic assessments conducted to identify relevant economic interventions in targeted municipalities - 0 3.2 Number of new jobs created with UNDP support (disaggregated by beneficiary group (IDPs, migrants and refugees, and where feasible by gender and age) - 525 (baseline 513 + new 11 of which 5 women). Innovation Challenge in Sebha and Benghazi 3.3 Number of start-ups and small businesses supported/created in Libya (disaggregated by gender) - 22 (baseline 12 + new 10 are being supported of which 5 owned by women). 3.4 Number of demand-driven apprenticeship programmes organized in partnership with private sector companies. - 3 (baseline) Engagement with Toyota being finalized 3.5. Number of people benefiting from apprenticeship programmes disaggregated by gender, age and type of training (e.g. TVET, IT and skills training etc.) - 700 (baseline)

The rehabilitation of the 10 health facilities supported by the SLCRR project have served as main healthcare service points in Benghazi, Kufra, Sabratha, Sebha, Murzuq, Ghat and Thala. These facilities are used for conducting COVID-19 tests and receiving sick patients
